lines.text:
[to Jim]
You have too much pride in your humility.

[to Cornelius]
You have a natural talent for disaster! Try and improve yourself into an ordinary failure by keeping your mouth shut.

[first lines; narrating]
Joseph Conrad wrote, "If you want to know the age of the Earth, look upon the sea in a storm." But what storm could fully reveal the heart of a man?

I've been a so-called coward and a so-called hero and there's not the thickness of a sheet of paper between them. Maybe cowards and heroes are just ordinary men who, for a split second, do something out of the ordinary. That's all.
The Captain of this ship is... do you know Gentleman Brown?
For this sort of work, we don't need any gentlemen.

[laughs]
This "Gentleman" Captain Brown has given more business to Death than the bubonic plague. From Java to Fiji, he's wanted for piracy, slavery, mutiny, rape, murder, and some things that aren't even mentioned in the Bible!
If an army couldn't get this treasure out, what makes you think that we can?
The General was too ambitious. We just need to eliminate a certain... person.
You mean murder?
Justice. Kill one pompous fool...
You're out, he's in - and *he's* the fool?
Now, where is this gold kept, is it guarded, if so, how, and by whom?
How do I know I can trust you?
You don't know.
What do you think?

[shrugs]
I'm a silent partner.
Then I suppose we'll have to take each other's word as gentlemen?

[sighs]
I suppose.
Could you do what he did?
Who knows? Under certain conditions, fear will come to any man. It's always there, waiting for us...

[Narrating]
One hope kept Jim going - a hope common to most men. Rich or poor, strong or weak, who among us has not begged God for a second chance?
It might interest you to know that some men can never become heroes, and some heroes can never become men.
Some are lucky enough to become both.
Who says they are lucky?
I do not trust a man who does not respect money.

[talking about his abdomen]
Oh, I feel a gripping pain here, probably something I ate.
Probably a precious stone perhaps. Like all thingsgreat and small, it will pass, and when it does, give it back.

[referring to Jim]
I think his majesty had pretentions to heroism, a form of mental disease induced by vanity.
You must face the truth.

Truth? What is the truth? I've been a so-called coward and a so-called hero, and there's not the thickness of a piece off paper between them. Maybe cowards and heroes are just ordinary men, who for just a split second do something that is out of the ordinary. That's all.

Ever wondered what it is that pain unbearable? The brain. Put the brain to sleep, and the flesh can be burned, torn, twisted... Awaken the brain, and every sight, sound, smell becomes exaggerated. Anticipate the pain... and finally, the pain becomes unbearable.
Do bullets not frighten you?
Fools frighten me.
What do you think of before a battle? Death? Killing? God? A woman!
I think only of what the enemy is thinking.

[to Cornelius after breaking his liquor bottle with his sword]
Drunk, you're useless... unreliable!
Sober he's the same.
